channel.title: W3C Web Applications Working Group-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by W3C Web Applications Working Group

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] Confusing "consider instead" note
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBTransaction/error_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

"Note:" callout in introduction

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The "consider listening error instead" text is confusing - it's not grammatical (should be something like "consider listening to error instead", and it links to itself. (I.e., it's saying "Consider listening to the error event instead of the error event," which doesn't make sense.)

What did you expect to see?

Was the intention to link to the abort event instead? I'm not an expert on the IndexedDB APIs, so I do not know.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbtransaction/error_event
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBTransaction/error_event
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/idbtransaction/error_event/index.md
  • Last commit: eab4066
  • Document last modified: 2023-04-07T06:06:41.000Z

item.title: [uievents] Bad example to demonstrate MouseEvent.ctrlKey for Macintosh users
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/ctrlKey

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The test box in Result is not helpful since it doesn't demonstrate the concept for Macintosh users.

What did you expect to see?

One of three things:

  • A clear note which explicitly states that the result does not work on Macintosh
  • A solution (if possible) which works around the interception
  • A second example (or in the same note mentioned above) which demonstrates the equivalent example for Mac, that is using MouseEvent.metaKey

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

  • Apple intercepts ctrl + click as right click
  • This issue has been pointed out before in the last comment of #6624

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Thank you all for providing us with excellent documentation and an extremely fast and responsive site!

MDN metadata

Page report details

  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/ctrlKey

  • Last commit: ef75c17

item.title: [manifest-app-info] Web app manifests: Add `form_factor` member.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Manifest/screenshots

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The platform member

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page lists narrow and wide as valid platform values, but this has been changed and now uses a separate form_factor field.

What did you expect to see?

The second instance of platform to be renamed to form_factor

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/manifest-app-info/#form_factor-member
w3c/manifest-app-info@018e021

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Note that it is currently specced in a way that screenshots without a form_factor are always shown, but there's an ongoing discussion on what the behaviour should be here: https://crbug.com/1434316

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] versionchange is super important and hardly is given any attention
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBDatabase

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Events/versionchange

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

onversionchange is critical and if not implemented can lead to user data corruption or loss. Running different versions in different tabs is a problem and the versionchange event solves this. Not a single thing is mentioned about this except some weak verbage of "An event fired when a database structure change was requested."

What did you expect to see?

I expect for this critical user data loss subject to be at least mentioned and even better showing some code supporting good practices for multiple tabs being open.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Ivan V. brings focus to this critical topic Handling IndexedDB Upgrade Version Conflict

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The documentation here is pretty weak too. It just casually grazes the subject saying "was requested elsewhere (most probably in another window/tab on the same computer)"
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBDatabase/versionchange_event

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbdatabase
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBDatabase
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/idbdatabase/index.md
  • Last commit: 89c582f
  • Document last modified: 2023-03-21T06:14:00.000Z

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] leading the developer down a dead end in onupgradeneeded
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBDatabase

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Example code

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example code that is provided leads the developer to a dead end. The onupgradeneeded gets called when initializing from no database but when the next version comes you will get an error when you get to the line that calls db.createObjectStore because the database has already been created. The example code is using bad form.

What did you expect to see?

I expect to see code that is actually usable IRL and not just in some one-shot example that is stuck on the initial version and can't upgrade in the future. (the example uses version "4" which is impossible to iterate incrementally to version 4 from version 1 using this code). Even the "complete working example" that the documentation mentions does this same mistake that can't ever upgrade past the initial version.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Here is someone that is as lost as I am asking the same question 3 years ago. Only one answer from Josh and I don't even think the answer is correct and it also lacks useful details as Robert Wilding comments. Robert did research and also brings up that "a good walkthrough on how to build and keep a proper migration path seems to be missing." I agree with Robert.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbdatabase
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBDatabase

  • Last commit: 89c582f
  • Document last modified: 2023-03-21T06:14:00.000Z

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] IDBObjectStore.openCursor incorrect direction docs
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/openCursor#parameters

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

IDBObjectStore.openCursor direction argument

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

prev option gets very confusing (The cursor is opened at the start(??) of the store) until you find out that it's just incorrectly documented specifically on this page.

What did you expect to see?

Definitely not that direction=prev would open cursor at the start of the store.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Example of properly documented openKeyCursor: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/openKeyCursor#parameters.
Properly documented IDBCursor.direction: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBCursor/direction#value

No response

item.title: [FileAPI] More information about text encoding when creating a Blob
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Blob/Blob

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The note about strings under description of the array parameter

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The note for strings under the array parameter description states

Note that strings here are encoded as UTF-8, unlike the usual JavaScript UTF-16 strings.

This can be confusing and could be interpreted as meaning strings provided should be encoded in utf8 already and that standard JavaScript strings are not acceptable.

What did you expect to see?

Possibly a note worded more along the lines of

Note that string items in array are treated as Unicode text and serialized in Blob output using utf8 encoding. In particular, providing base64 or binary string values in array never converts them to binary data when a Blob is serialized.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

processing Blob Parts under Contructor parameters in the FIle API standard.

USVString in the Web IDL standard.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBCursor/key

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The article says:

Within each iteration we log the key of the cursor to the console, something like this

However, there looks no examples of keys to be logged corresponding to "something like this" in the page.

What did you expect to see?

An example of a key to be logged is added.

item.title: [clipboard-apis] clipboard.readText() is behind flag on Firefox
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Interact_with_the_clipboard

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

However, while navigator.clipboard.readText() and navigator.clipboard.writeText() work on all browsers

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

clipboard.readText() is behind flag on Firefox dom.events.asyncClipboard.readText in about:config, which is also not mentioned on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/readText.

What did you expect to see?

Conspicuous notes on both https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/readText and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Interact_with_the_clipboard stating the flag that needs to be used on Firefox to enable navigator.clipboard.readText() and removal of the claim

However, while navigator.clipboard.readText() and navigator.clipboard.writeText() work on all browsers

which is not accurate when running Nightly 110 out of the box.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

item.title: [html, uievents] Document.activeElement : The lack of HTMLAnchorElement and macOS on a case by case basis
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/API/Document/activeElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Document.activeElement

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Hello,

The introduction of the article (and the entire content) is totally focused on input elements.

The most common cases

Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object.

However, in the major operating systems (OS) and browsers (I tested only on 4), the HTMLAnchorElement (A element) is focusable.

In the era of accessibility, for those who navigate with the keyboard, and for all those (everybody) who click on a link (A or an internal anchor #) : the focus is triggered and the Document.activeElement returns anHTMLAnchorElement.

And there are often more links (A links) in a page than input elements. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This can be confusing, when you see yourself that the majority of the elements not mentioned in the article take the focus by default, in general.

The case of macOS

There is an exception on macOS (which is specified in the article), but by looking for information about Document.activeContent, it seems to me that more explanations can be provided.

Which elements are focusable varies depending on the platform and the browser's current configuration. For example, on macOS systems, elements that aren't text input elements are not typically focusable by default.

This is true, but a clarification can be added : on macOS only some browsers take into account the default configuration of the operating system : Safari and Chrome do, but Firefox and Microsoft Edge do not. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This last information can be confusing when looing for information about Document.activeElement. Indeed, with the default macOS configuration, if when testing on Chome the A elements are not focusable but when testing on Firefox they are, the article does not really open your eyes to the macOS configuration (which is not taken into account by at least half of the browsers).

What did you expect to see?

It can be expected the HTMLAnchorElement to be referenced as a focusable element.
Alternatively, the sentence the "Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object" could be modified to explain the context of this specification. The writer(s) are probably thinking of the use of Document.activeElement in the listener of a FocusEvent whose target would be a HTMLInputElement or a HTMLTextareaElement, but as a developer it is interesting to have a more global view.

Of course, the precision regarding macOS should be retained, but perhaps adding that "some elements are not typically focusable by default" is also browser dependent on macOS (regardeless the configuration). This could avoid extensive research into why it works on one browser but not the other.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

For example, on the page Document.activeElement, by counting focusable elements.

Most common cases

The HTMLAnchorElement are focusable on Linux, on Windows and on macOS (with the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls"), and it seems that this is for all browsers :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox/Edge/Chrome/Safari 215 15 1

The case of macOS

On macOS, with default OS configuration (without the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls" so) :

Brower  HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox 215 15 1
Microsoft Edge 215 15 1
Chome 0 15 1
Safari 0 0 1

item.title: [cssom-view-1, uievents, pointerlock-2] MouseEvent.clientX and MouseEvent.clientY is the coordinates of the window, but the documentation is written relative to the local dom
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

MouseEvent.clientX and MouseEvent.clientY

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

MouseEvent.clientX and MouseEvent.clientY is the coordinates of the window, but the documentation is written relative to the local dom。

the page correct:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/clientX

What did you expect to see?

The clientX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the horizontal coordinate within the application's viewport at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinate within the page).

For example, clicking on the left edge of the viewport will always result in a mouse event with a clientX value of 0, regardless of whether the page is scrolled horizontally.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/clientX
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MouseEvent/clientY
  • w3c: https://www.w3.org/TR/2022/WD-uievents-20220913/#dom-mouseeventinit-clientx

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/mouseevent

item.title: [uievents] Browser inconsistency on Element click event types (MouseEvent versus PointerEvent)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/click_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Event Type

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It says event type is "MouseEvent". This is the case for Firefox now, but Chrome returns "PointerEvent".

If I didn't try for myself on Chrome, I would think there is no easy way to distinguish between clicks of "mouse", "pen" or "touch".

https://w3c.github.io/uievents/#event-type-click

Spec says "Interface PointerEvent"

What did you expect to see?

Page should show that according to spec, click event is PointerEvent and it should show its related properties like "pointerType".

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/uievents/#event-type-click

Do you have anything more you want to share?

<div>CLICK ME</div>
document.querySelector("div").addEventListener("click", console.log);

Try this on Firefox and Chrome. I tested on:
Firefox 105.0.2 (64-bit)
Chrome Version 106.0.5249.119 (Official Build) (64-bit)

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/element/click_event
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/click_event
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/element/click_event/index.md
  • Last commit: 5cfd133
  • Document last modified: 2022-09-22T08:13:42.000Z

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] indexedDB.deleteDatabase doc: Mention that deleting a database isn't completed until the upgradeNeeded result is closed
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBFactory/deleteDatabase

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When calling IDBFactory.deleteDatabase(), the database isn't deleted until the upgradeneeded event is garbage collected, which can by triggered by calling request.result.close() on the indexedDB.open() result.

What did you expect to see?

Mention that onsuccess won't be fired until the indexedDB.open() result is closed like so:

const request = indexedDB.open(dbName);
request.onupgradeneeded = () => {
  request.result.close();
}

though to be honest I'm not sure how much of this depends on my specific situation. I reckon there might be other calls that similarly cause a database to stay open like this.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Initially I thought this was a bug in Chrome, so I reported https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1359843. But it seems like this behaviour is intentional.
You can find an example of this behaviour at https://indexeddb-deletedatabase-hanging.glitch.me/
you'll see that unless you have the 'close indexedDB.open() result' checkbox checked, deleting databases will take significantly longer depending on how fast the objects are garbage collected.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbfactory/deletedatabase
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBFactory/deleteDatabase
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/idbfactory/deletedatabase/index.md
  • Last commit: 916af5e
  • Document last modified: 2022-08-04T06:19:25.000Z

const mouseEvent = document.createEvent("MouseEvent")

item.title: [uievents] Event references should list bubbles, cancelable, and composed values
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/click_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The event reference documentation did not give the values of the bubbles, cancelable, and composed properties.

What did you expect to see?

The values of the bubbles, cancelable, and composed properties of the event.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The old documentation used to give the values of the bubbles and cancelable properties:

https://web.archive.org/web/20220104000330/https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/click_event

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I gave an example of one event, "click", but this issue applies to every event reference.

item.title: [uievents] Document the ability to preventDefault() a pinch-zoom gesture on a touchpad
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/wheel_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Firefox and Chrome (and maybe other browsers) allow websites to opt out of the browser's default handling of a touchpad pinch gesture (which is to zoom the page, either in a reflowing or a smooth/non-reflowing way depending on the browser version and touchpad hardware), by synthesizing a wheel event (with a modifier, usually Ctrl or Cmd depending on the platform) and giving the page a chance to preventDefault() the wheel event.

This is not very discoverable, since there isn't an obvious link between a pinch gesture and a wheel event.

(My understanding is, a wheel event was chosen for the following reasons:

  1. There isn't another event type in the web platform that would correspond more directly to a touchpad pinch gesture.
  2. Ctrl+wheel also causes zooming, and preventDefault()ing Ctrl+wheel was an existing way for sites to opt out of zooming, so it made sense to extend that to zooming caused by a touchpad gesture.)

What did you expect to see?

It would be nice to document this behaviour on MDN. Specifically, that:

  1. A touchpad pinch-zoom gesture results in the browser synthesizing a wheel event
  2. The zooming that's the browser's default behaviour in reponse to the gesture can be prevented using preventDefault() on that event

Not sure where the best place to document this is -- maybe the wheel event page? I'm open to suggestions.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I implemented this behaviour in Firefox. Investigation of Chrome's similar behaviour is documented in bug 1619187. More recent testing suggests Safari now has the same behaviour as well.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] IDBObjectStore»add() example: incomplete basic explanation; unclear how ConstraintError is handled
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/add

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Errors, Exceptions

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It is unclear how ConstraintError is handled.
Text says "If a record already exists in the object store with the key parameter as its key, then an error ConstrainError event is fired on the returned request object."
OK. How do I tell in my "onerror" method if it is a ConstraintError or otherwise? Is the "event" object passed to the "onerror" method an instance of Error? Event? hybrid? Error a property of Event?
Text says "This method may raise a [DOMException] of one of the following types:"
OK. When? The example does not handle a DOMException, just an "onerror" method.
In fact, the example confusingly applies the "onerror" to the transaction, not the request object as stated (yea, I know it bubbles to the transaction, but the example is still confusing if that is not noted to the beginner)
If I could:
try { transaction.objectStore(store).add(foo); }
catch(e) { (e instanceof ConstraintError) ? ......... }
then I could move forward.
It's a lot of work to create a database, fill it, then try to create errors and probe results from there.

What did you expect to see?

a complete reference to the method

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbobjectstore/add
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/add
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/idbobjectstore/add/index.md
  • Last commit: 281e3b2
  • Document last modified: 2022-02-18T09:53:31.000Z

item.title: [html, gamepad] Double checking the gamepad docs are correct
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

/en-US/docs/Web/API/Gamepad_API/Using_the_Gamepad_API

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Multiple sections

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I could be reading the article wrong but ... stuff like this

Note: The Gamepad object is available on the gamepadconnected event rather than the Window object itself, for security reasons. Once we have a reference to it, we can query its properties for information about the current state of the gamepad. Behind the scenes, this object will be updated every time the gamepad's state changes.

What did you expect to see?

AFAIK This wrong.

#1. While it's true a gamepad object will be provided on gamepadconnected, it's also true that gamepad objects will be provided by navigator.getGamepads

#2. The description above and elsewhere suggests holding on to a reference to the gamepad object and querying it for values. But this fails. In fact, the example code in the article does not do this. It updates the gamepad objects near the end

       controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];

In other words, it's updating the controllers array with a new gamepad object for the same gamepad.

If instead you did this

   // no need to use a new gamepad object if we already have a gamepad object
   // for this controller from the gamepadconnected event
   if (!controllers[gamepads[i].index]) {
      controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];
   }

You'd see the example would fail. At least in Chrome I get a few readings and then gamepad object I was holding a reference too goes dead. Where as if I made sure to get new gamepad objects by calling navigator.getGamepads then the code keeps running.

Let me add, holding on to a reference used to work. I was grabbing some old code that held references and I know worked great when I wrote it 7 yrs ago but suddenly it was not working. I tracked the issue down to this. You can't keep a reference to the gamepad object. You need to take new ones by calling getGamepads

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/gamepad_api/using_the_gamepad_api
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Gamepad_API/Using_the_Gamepad_API
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/gamepad_api/using_the_gamepad_api/index.md
  • Last commit: 593f9ac
  • Document last modified: 2022-04-02T17:42:56.000Z

item.title: [uievents] “mouseleave is fired when the pointer has exited the element” is inaccurate
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseleave_event

Specific page section or heading?

Most of it, but particularly in the introduction: "...mouseleave is fired when the pointer has exited the element..."

What is the problem?

In fact, the mouseleave event fires on an IMG if the pointer enters an AREA defined in a MAP referenced by an IMG - even if that AREA is entirely within the image. In my mental model, an area is a part of an image; leaving it does not imply I have left the image. (Though both Chrome and Firefox behave as if it does imply leaving the image.)

What did you expect to see?

Well, an accurate description :-).

Perhaps a more thorough definition of "exit". A MAP seems to present a problem specific to an IMG element. Neither the map, nor its areas, seems to have a heirarchial relationship to the image, so it's not covered by the discussion of hierarchy.

Perhaps add somewhere "In the case of an image map, the cursor is considered to have left the image when it enters an area, even if that area is contained entirely within the image. Similarly, when the cursor exits an area but remains within the image, a mouseleave event on the area will fire, and a mouseenter event on the image will also fire."

I should probably go to W3 to see if someone addressed the issue...

Did you test this? If so, how?

Tediously.

I attached a single mouseenter handler, and a single mouseleave handler, to every IMG and AREA on a page. They log messages to the console. I'll guess that anyone reading this will immediately recognize what I have not understood, and the details are not necessary. I'm omitting them to reduce clutter, but will happily provide code and logs on request :-)

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] Issue with "IDBTransaction.oncomplete": When transaction's oncomplete is actually called?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBTransaction/oncomplete

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It mentioned open a read/write transaction on our database and add SOME data to an object store but in example only shows single objectStore.add(). So it's still confusing when transaction's oncomplete is actually called since there is no transaction closing command anywhere.

Specific section or headline?

In Example part

What did you expect to see?

Show an example with multiple objectStore's operations to make it clear when oncomplete is actually called

Did you test this? If so, how?

No. It should be well documented.

  • Document last modified: 2021-12-07T10:49:24.000Z

item.title: [uievents] Content bug: Missing information about what WheelEvent.delta* can be
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaX
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaY
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaZ
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaMode

What is the problem?

Missing information described in w3c/uievents#181 (comment)
And the change in Firefox caused by Intent to ship: Return pixel deltas in wheel event if deltaMode is not checked by authors, that modify the behavior to the following, decided per event:

  • If deltaMode has been accessed, then the original delta mode and deltas are reported.

  • If deltaMode has not been accessed, and it's DOM_DELTA_LINE, accessing any of the deltas cause the event to always report DOM_DELTA_PIXELS, and the deltas get converted to pixels using the font-size of the target element.

For more information see:

  • w3c/uievents#181
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1392460

item.title: [pointerlock-2] Element.requestPointerLock() missing some useful detail
item.content:encoded:
Element/requestPointerLock is missing some useful detail from the spec. In particular that it requires transient activation and some of the ways it can fail - see https://w3c.github.io/pointerlock/#ref-for-dom-element-requestpointerlock-1

It may be worth waiting on doing this for the quite significant changes proposed in Add lock options to requestPointerLock - spec PR

item.title: [ecmascript, FileAPI] Clean up irrelevant notes about old browser releases
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileReader/error says:

In Chrome 48+/Firefox 58+ this property returns a DOMException because DOMError has been removed from the DOM standard.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/typeof#regular_expressions says:

typeof /s/ === 'function'; // Chrome 1-12 Non-conform to ECMAScript 5.1
typeof /s/ === 'object';   // Firefox 5+  Conform to ECMAScript 5.1

What is the problem?

Information about quirks in very old browser releases seems like a net negative for readers of MDN. It will require readers to make a judgement about whether this could affect them, by testing or looking at release dates for the browsers.

What did you expect to see?

Irrelevant information should be pruned from MDN after some time. Perhaps some special markup could be used when referring to a specific browser version, so that tools could be written to list information about browser releases too old to be relevant. Such cleanup happens to some extent in BCD, around irrelevant features removed from all browsers for more than 2 years, and also old flag data.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Searching for "Chrome " + a number of any other browser followed by a number can find many examples like these.

item.title: [html, uievents] Replace hand-written compat sections with BCD tables
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

These pages show browser compat without using BCD tables:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Games/Techniques/Controls_Gamepad_API#api_status_and_browser_support (prose)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/KeyboardEvent/keyCode#value_of_keycode (prose and tables)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Streams_API/Using_readable_streams#browser_support (prose)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Animations_API/Using_the_Web_Animations_API#browser_support (prose)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Audio_and_video_delivery/Cross-browser_audio_basics#browser_support (tables)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Audio_and_video_delivery/Live_streaming_web_audio_and_video#streaming_file_format_support (table)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Audio_and_video_delivery/WebAudio_playbackRate_explained#browser_support (bullet points)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/button#clicking_and_focus (tables)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Containers (tables)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Image_types (tables)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts/features_restricted_to_secure_contexts (tables)

What is the problem?

The information is presented in a different way to BCD tables used on most pages. For some of these pages there may be good reasons to maintain it by hand, but I suspect most could be replaced by linked BCD tables.

item.title: [uievents] Issue with "Element: keydown event": What generates a KeyboardEvent?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Please I don't understand what's meant by this paragraph in the MDN article:

Keyboard events are only generated by <inputs>, <textarea> and anything with the contentEditable attribute or with tabindex="-1".

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

They seem to be generated by arbitrary focusable elements. I expected something like:

Keyboard events are only generated by focusable elements. This includes <button>, <a>, <input>, <textarea>, and anything with the contenteditable or tabindex attributes.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I added listeners for the keydown and keyup events to an <a>, a <button> and a <span> with tabindex=0, and then when I typed while the elements were focused, the listeners got called.

I should also add that the listeners for these events that were attached to parents of the focusable elements also got called (I'm guessing this is because the event bubbles up).

MDN Content page report details

  • Last commit: 2279e5a
  • Document last modified: 2021-09-14T18:08:09.000Z

item.title: [clipboard-apis] Update execCommand use in context-menu-copy-link-with-types
item.content:encoded:
context-menu-copy-link-with-types uses a content script because when the example was written execCommand didn't work in background pages; now they do so the example should be updated to call execCommand from the background page instead of using a content script.

Note, before updating check whether Clipboard.write() is available in Firefox, as this would be the preferred method given that execCommand is deprecated.

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard/write
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons

item.title: [html, cssom-view-1, dom, WebIDL-1, FileAPI, uievents, pointerlock-2] Remove alert() from live samples
item.content:encoded:
window.alert() doesn't work cross-origin in Chrome any more, meaning that any of our live samples that rely on alert() are now broken.

See also #7553.

This is (I think) all the live samples in Web/API that use alert() in a live sample:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/attr/localname
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvasrenderingcontext2d/addhitregion
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document/querycommandstate
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/domexception/domexception
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventtarget/addeventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/file/name
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/keyboardevent/metakey
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/mouseevent
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/notifications_api/using_the_notifications_api
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/find
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/windoworworkerglobalscope/settimeout (fixed in #7560)

(I might have missed some).

We should replace all of these with some alternative. A common alternative is to write the output into an element in the example's document.

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] Issue with "IDBTransaction":Example needs explanation
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBTransaction

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Arguments passed to db.transaction in an example are unexplained.

Specific section or headline?

First js code example (under IDBTransaction), for example the line db.transaction("foo", "readwrite");

What did you expect to see?

Anything describing the meaning of the arguments, esp "foo" (which turns out to be a store name, and a special case of that first argument, which otherwise would be a list, not a string). A link to the "transaction" article i found (see below) would be useful here.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Did not test, but answered my own question with a google search for indexedDB transaction method, found the mozilla article ...IDBDatabase/transaction, which provided a lucid explanation.

A link to that article would be useful to rank amateurs like me.

At the same time, I have to comment that this mechanism for commenting on articles is new to me. Thank you for providing it. Earlier alternatives seemed to offer the opportunity to edit the article, and no way was I going to do that. It's especially nice to be able to reference the tab where the question arose as I complete this form.

item.title: [intersection-observer] Issue with "IntersectionObserver()": needs description/example of how rootMargin works
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserver/IntersectionObserver

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The description for rootMargin should indicate whether positive margins increase or decrease the threshold for intersection detection. This is particularly important because I can use margins to change the relative position of a box in CSS (e.g. I can move an element up 5 pixels by setting its top-margin to "-5px". The way the document describes this, it sounds like it functions more like CSS padding, such that setting the top value to "-5px" would decrease the size of the bounding box by 5px without moving the element.

Specific section or headline?

Parameters

What did you expect to see?

I'd like to see the description of how rootMargin works show how the option works, or at least describe its operations by stating more precisely which direction the bounding box grows (or moves?) when the value is positive vs when it is negative.

Did you test this? If so, how?

N/A
